It took three months for Helen to finally flip her lid over her roommate. Combined with the summer months, that was nearly half a year of stable, sane behavior for the new college freshman. Helen had always had problems keeping her cool, was too quick to take offense were none was intend, too prone to fly into "psychotic rampages of revenge," as her therapist put it. She thought college would be different, and for a while, it was. Being away from the high school that tormented her so was a huge weight off her back. Being able to focus on her studies was another plus. Certainly being away from her paranoid, controlling parents was probably the biggest contribution to her stability of mind.

The first personl Helen really talked to at college was her roommate Pasim. She was polite enough, didn't do anything to annoy Helen, and so was all right in her eyes. At first, the two girls were too wrapped up in their studies to really notice each other. Helen had no interest in making new friends, having been burned by too many in the past, and Pasim was too focused on her fashion studies. They did get along, though, since Pasim recognized Helen's distance and didn't force herself on her, and Helen grew to actually like Pasim despite not exchanging many words.

Two situations endured Pasim to Helen within weeks of the start of the semester. The first happened when Helen happened to walk by Pasim's room while she was getting dressed. She glanced over out of habit, not particularly curious as to what she was doing in her own room. Helen saw Pasim standing straight up, profile to her mirror, sucking her soft but mostly flat stomach in while she lifted up her shirt. Pasim sighed, letting her stomach out, it bulging just slightly over her pants. Biting her lip with a look of concern, she looked back and felt her prominent ass. She sighed again, a sound of such quiet, sad acceptance that to Helen, who herself never concerned herself with her weight and maintained an average, healthy weight, made Pasim suddenly seem a lot more human.

Finding out that Pasim went to the gym at least three times a week, that she could never get herself below 150 pounds despite all this hard work, made Pasim extremely sympathetic to Helen. Subconsciously Helen was associating Pasim's struggle with her figure to her own struggle with her self-identity in high school, but outwardly she only knew she felt bad for her roommate. From then on, she took the time to make small talk with her. She even introduced her childhood friend Adam to her, something she was loathe to do with any other classmates she began talking to.

The second endearing thing was more universal--Pasim worked at the campus Starbucks and brought home leftover pastries when she worked late. Pasim may have bemoaned how hard it was to keep her weight down, but that didn't stop Helen from snacking every other night on high-calorie bread products.

Pasim was grateful, actually. She hated throwing away food, an attitude drilled into her by her moth and, she was convinced, was responsible for her curvy, very un-model-like figure. So for Pasim she avoided the mom-given guilt of wasting free food, and didn't have to take any of the caloric bullets for herself. It was win/win.

The two both felt the same stresses of college life that all students do. But whereas Pasim transferred this stress to worries for her figure, Helen let it build and build, until her fragile psych finally had had enough . . .

Helen rolled her eyes, exasperated.

"You look the same as you did when we first met," Helen said. "Stop obsessing."

Pasim leaned out to look at Helen.

"Easy for you to--" she stopped, squinting. She was so conscious of every pound on her body that she hadn't noticed that college was taking its toll on her roommate's figure, too. Helen had an average build to start with, but now she was looking softer. Her shirt even rode up over her stomach, which was bulging out just slightly and merging into the start of lovehandles.

Pasim must have stared too long and given her a strange look, because Helen looked concerned suddenly.

"What? What is it?"

Pasim was obviously staring at Helen's pouting stomach. Helen looked down at it and back at Pasim, confused.

"Nothing, nothing," Pasim said. It was just a few pounds anyways, she told herself. No sense in offending Helen. She was high strung enough as it is.

Helen turned back to her show slowly, paranoid thoughts going through her head as to what exactly her roommate was thinking just now. Pasim might have been handling the strain of college well, but for Helen, each day was bringing new and more annoyances. She was doing poorly in her classes. She was starting to think the same paranoid thoughts she had in high school about teachers intentionally failing her, about classmates laughing at her behind her back for her stupid comments in class. Adam told her to take it easy but that just made Helen more frustrated. And to top it off, Pasim's increasing obsession with her weight was starting to really get to her.

Helen fumed, not sure exactly what she was so mad about but knowing there must be a cause, and it was probably Pasim. Without so much as a bye, she left to talk to Adam. He could calm her down at least.

"Hey, Helen, want any--Oh, um, bye?" Pasim said to an empty room.

------------

". . . and I swear he was looking at me when he said it, like he was so much smarter than me and the professor knew it. College was supposed to be different from high school. Why are people such assholes here?" Helen snacked on some chips while Adam sat in a chair across from her.

"You can't take things so personally," Adam said, as he often did. "Maybe if you, you know, made nice with some of these people you'd wind up liking them. Your roommate's nice, right? I thought she was pretty cool."

"Oh, she's another one," Helen said, feeling that strange, unexplained anger at Pasim that had been growing. "She won't shut up about her weight. I know she's all into fashion and stuff but it's all she ever talks about. She'll look exactly the same as always and be convinced that, I don't know, she's gained a hundred pounds."

"What, you don't like her body image thing? When you first told me she had these issues you talked about it like it was some heroic struggle against society for her, or something. Now it bugs you?"

"It seems a lot more self-centered and petty when it's all she ever talks about," Helen snapped. "I know I gained a few pounds but it doesn't bother me."

"The price of all those delicious cupcakes and muffins and such," Adam nodded, himself often partaking of Pasim's work leftovers.

"Yeah, it's--" Helen stopped, her expression suddenly turning very thoughtful.

"What?"

"Wait a minute," Helen thought, the wheels obviously turning in her head. She was making connections--paranoid, conspiratorial connections, like the kind she did during the four-year-long nervous breakdown that was high school. Something wasn't right, she knew it, and now she had a handle on it. Pasim's obsession with her own weight. Bringing way too many fatty snacks back to the dorm nearly every night. All that talk about her own weight, those queer looks she kept giving Helen, and the way she was staring at her stomach earlier . . .

"Oh no. No way," Helen said quietly.

"Now, let's wait a second, Helen," Adam said, knowing that look. "I want you to really consider carefully everything you just thought through.

Helen nodded firmly and squeezed some flab at her waist.

"It was her, she did this," Helen said, her voice rising. "She's been doing it from the start. All that food, all the talk about weight to distract me--"

"Slow down," Adam said, holding his hands level and speaking in as soothing a voice as he could.

Helen didn't speak again right away. This was how it was with her. Things would build up, phrases and looks would be blown out of proportion, and then something insignificant would happen and she would suddenly have the idea that she uncovered some vast conspiracy. She growled, breathing deeply.

"Helen, listen," Adam took a conversational tone. He wasn't entirely sure what he was accusing Pasim of but he knew it was insane and he needed to talk her down from it. "Remember when Amber and Cody went to all that trouble for months to plan that surprise party for you but you eventually thought they were trying to get everyone to ignore you like you didn't exist?"

"Well, that's what happened wasn't it?"

"You blew up and tore them both a new one in front of the whole class!"

"Why do you always take everybody else's side but mine? Look at this," Helen stood up and pushed her now soft stomach up.

"What? People put on weight in college. It happens. What's the big deal?"

"Yeah, but how come I barely even noticed until now? How come Pasim keeps trying to distract me by talking about her weight, and feeding me all those treats--"

"She didn't force you, and it's awesome of her to share. Look, you still look great--"

"I know I look great, it's the principal of the thing. I don't care about the weight. I'm not some vanity-crazed sociopath who fattens her roommates up for her own amusement--" Helen's voice was taking on a frantic, shrill tone now. Adam was ready to bow out. There was no talking sense to her now. When she was this far gone in her delusions it was often best to leave her to her own devices and, usually, the next time you saw her she pretended it never happened.

"Why would she do that, Helen? She's a busy college student like you. She has her own problems without making some for you for no reason."

"I don't know why she'd do it," Helen said. "Probably to make herself feel better, so that she wouldn't have to be the fat one. Well, she's still got thirty pounds on me at least and I'll be damned if I put on any more weight for her pleasure. If anyone's getting fat it's her, her and her stupid fashion major, I oughta' shove every muffin in that stupid coffee house until she's too fat to, to--gaaah!"

Helen clenched her fists and paced, becoming so wrapped up she could barely speak.

"Helen, don't do--or say--anything you can't take back," Adam stood and said firmly.

I see how it is, Helen thought, staring Adam down. You're too nice for your own good sometimes. Anyone can see Pasim is a self-absorbed bitch who only acts nice so she can mess with you. But you like her don't you, you always said so? Oh, I see it now. It's all right if mean old Helen gets fat but your plump little Indian princess has to stay just as she is, because you have eyes for her and you know that it wouldn't take much to turn a curvy, sexy girl like her into a fat, waddling pig . . .

"Helen? Helen, are you listening to me?"

"What?" Helen snapped back to reality. That mental conversation calmed her down, but also made her more certain than before that Pasim's nice girl act was just a front to manipulate others. She almost got Helen, too. If she hadn't caught on now when she did she might have gotten so big she'd never be thin again. And if she got her hands on Adam, she'd whip him into her personal slave and Helen would probably never see him again.

"Okay. I'm calm. I'm sorry," Helen said slowly, already walking to the door.

"Wait, where are you going? Promise me, Helen, that you won't say anything, um, like that, to Pasim? I thinks you're a good friend. You don't want to blow another friendship."

Helen sighed as she opened the door to go.

"Okay, I won't say anything to her. Promise. Thanks for being here for me," she smiled faintly.

"What are friends for?" Adam smirked back, but Helen had already closed the door.

There was only one thing to do, Helen thought, both for revenge and to protect herself and her one true friend. She had to fatten up Pasim, by any means necessary.

So how does she go about this?

Sally Rhonda Anagnos, though her friends usually referred to her as Sally Rhonda or simply Sally (many were amazed that her last name wasn't actually Rhonda), was studying Comp Sci at M---- University. She'd always had a life long interest in science, and computers in particular, so it had seemed a natural fit. Moments like this, however, made her question some of her choices in life.

She'd been playing CoH far, far later into the weekend then she'd initially planned, and now found herself scrambling to finish this bit of code before class on Monday. Four hours ago, she'd found a bug in her code, but a missing closed paren had put it right.

This somehow created two bugs.

Fixing those somehow created four bugs.

Now she was up to six bugs, and was really considering taking a fire axe to her computer screen.

Sliding her reading glasses back on her face, she pushed a strand of her long, black hair behind her ear and kept looking. Feeling an unexpected hand on her shoulder, Sally nearly jumped out of her chair and let out a squeal in shock. She felt the figure behind her flinch and turned to see her room mate, Catherine, behind her. She took her ear buds out, filling the room with a steady bass beat.

Cathy was blushing furiously as she said, "Sorry, I didn't mean to scare you like that. Um, there's a pizza guy here at the door, and I didn't order any..."

"Oh! Yeah, that's mine. Thanks for telling me!" Sally hopped out of her chair. Grabbing her wallet, she went to the door to pay for her food, Cathy's eyes locked on her behind the entire time.

The two women had been room mates their first year in the dorms, and having gotten along so well, decided to get an apartment together for their second year. Over the past year and a half that she'd known her, Cathy had watched Sally slowly but steadily put on some weight. "She's certainly filling out those sweat pants more then she used to, that's for sure," Cathy thought as she watched how Sally's bottom stretched the material out to the sides and back more then they had even two weeks ago.

It really wasn't hard to figure out why. In the entire time she'd known her, she'd never seen Sally do any exercise more strenuous then walk to class. At the same time, she was a soft drink junkie who refused to touch water. Cathy had come to believe contact with vegetables or fruit would make her melt, and she seemed intent on eating greasy takeout for as many meals as possible.

Over the past six months, her snacking and pizza binges had become increasingly frequent. An entire box of Twinkies as a study snack was rapidly becoming the new norm, and she seemed to need pizza whenever she was working on a project. And at three projects a week, that basically translated to all the time.

Having paid for her pizza, Sally closed the door and turned around. Cathy had a good look at her friend's belly as she walked back to her desk. While it wasn't all that easy to tell under Sally's baggy t-shirt, she was pretty certain her gut was indeed larger then it had been not too long ago. Occasionally she could catch a glimpse of it as the material pinched just right. She could clearly make out two rolls, and she was positive that they were wider and hanging lower then before.

While she wasn't too worried yet, Cathy felt like she had to say something, as Sally would eventually blow up like a house if she held her current course. Trying her best to remain diplomatic, she said, "Pizza again? We just ate supper a few hours ago."

"Yeah, but this code is giving me a wicked head ache, and I don't think well on an empty stomach."

"When was the last time your stomach was ever empty?" Cathy thought, though she didn't voice it aloud.

Sally, meanwhile, had grabbed her first slice of pizza and took a big bite. She happily chewed, blissfully unaware of the changes to her body. She'd never watched what she ate or worried about her figure before. That, combined with her generally baggy wardrobe, left her totally in the dark regarding how her body had already grown, and what further changes were coming because of that.

A few weeks later, Sally was feeling overwhelmed. Project after project meant hours upon hours of transcribing code, fixing bugs, and even scrapping entire days' worth of work to start anew. Sally was burned out regularly, being too exhausted during what little free time she had to do much more than veg out playing video games or streaming low-brow TV serials. This also meant that Sally spent quite a bit of time at her desk, with her physical activity being limited mostly to walking to and from class and occasionally getting up to go to the fridge or pick up her takeout.

This, combined with her generally poor diet, had a definite effect on Sally's waistline. The young woman had really ballooned, with thousands of calories worth of pizza, soda, and junk food accumulating as thick, blubbery fat on her figure, pushing her baggy wardrobe to the limit. Most of the weight collected around her middle and lower half, but if that bothered Sally, she didn't let on. The waistband of her sweats was certainly getting rather tight, and her shirts were starting to ride up if she stretched the exhaustion out of her torso, but she wasn't quite at the point where she needed to get new clothes. If she continued along this track, though, it was only a matter of time.

Cathy, meanwhile, was another story. She was an English major, so her academic life presented a different set of challenges. Keeping up with assignments and exams was easy enough, but the real struggle came with balancing those things out with her new internship at the local newspaper. Municipal elections brought with them a certain upheaval in the newsroom, and it took all Cathy had to get a grip on the needs of her fair but demanding editors, the ever-present backlog of coursework, and the day-to-day parts of living. Cathy spent much of her time away from home these days, and while she did note with concern how much Sally was blowing up, there wasn't a lot of time for her to do something about it.

This morning, though, Cathy had a different concern: a pair of jeans that wouldn't button. She eventually gave up and opted for some stretch pants that day, but the experience had prompted her to step on a scale. With baited breath, she watched the numbers settle into place.

The 19 year old student sighed at the results the scale. She'd lost five pounds since the last time she weighed in.

Emma was always an introvert, mainly keeping to herself. She could be generous and helpful when she needed to, but she mostly preferred to live alone in her apartment dorm.

But deep down, she sometimes wished that she could become more noticeable, to be taller or have a more unique body. But as skinny and short as she was, it was very difficult to stand out, whether it be physically or emotionally.

She ended her thoughts with a sigh, and went on to one of her favorite hobbies: cooking.

Her favorite class in the whole college was cooking, as she felt it could let her active mind pass to others without really even speaking. Plus, it just felt nice to make others happy by cooking them good food. She was currently working on a project that, for a change, she was incredibly excited about and willing to get done early... to cook an assortment of snacks and share them to the class.

Vouching for a batch of her special cookies, she went right to work. As she scurried about the kitchen, she constantly passed a counter next to the stove, where an assortment of ingredients began to materialize.

"All I need is...sugar!" she opened a pantry beneath the kitchen utensil drawer, and pulled out a massive bag of sugar the size of a shopping bag. With all her strength, she heaved it onto the counter.

BLAM!!!

She yelped in shock as a massive clap of thunder shook the entire complex, leaving her stunned shaking. A massive snowstorm was raging outside, which intimidated her even more now that it was paired with lightning.

"Don't think about it, Emma...you can do this!"

The ingredients went in, one by one. As she worked, the thunderstorm still raged on.

She was just about to place the sugar in last ingredient.

But just as she opened the bag...

BLAM!!!!!

She shrieked in horror as the room quaked and the lights went out, leaving the room. Just as darkness appeared, a bursting noise came from above, and an array of blue sparks emanated from the sugar bag before her.

The lights came back on, but Emma was in shock when she saw that a wire had came loose from the light above and landed in the sugar. She instantly unplugged the light and withdrew the cord, relieved to find the sugar still intact.

So she went ahead and added the sugar to the dough. As the shock from the sudden lightning burst wore off, the process went along without a hitch.

After two hours of cooking, she was left with five large boxes filled with cookies.

"Now for my favorite part, the taste-test!"

She picked a random cookie from the box, and chewed it.

Much to her surprise, it was the single best cookie she had ever eaten...unlike her usual recipe, this seemed to have some sort of wonderful essence put into it!
